items.title: Cuba says border guards killed four people on US-registered speedboat
items.standfirst: Rare clash off island’s coast comes amid oil embargo and heightened tensions between two countries The Cuban Interior Ministry has said that border guards killed four people and wounded six more on a speedboat bearing a Florida registration off Cayo Falcones in Cuba’s Villa Clara province.The Cuban government claimed that its border guards had been fired upon during the incident off the coast of Cuba. The alleged clash comes at a moment of heightened tensions between the United States and Cuba during an oil embargo that has led to an energy and humanitarian crisis on the island. Continue reading...
items.content: Rare clash off island’s coast comes amid oil embargo and heightened tensions between two countries The Cuban Interior Ministry has said that border guards killed four people and wounded six more on a speedboat bearing a Florida registration off Cayo Falcones in Cuba’s Villa Clara province.The Cuban government claimed that its border guards had been fired upon during the incident off the coast of Cuba. The alleged clash comes at a moment of heightened tensions between the United States and Cuba during an oil embargo that has led to an energy and humanitarian crisis on the island. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Politician brothers convicted in Brazil for ordering murder of prominent councillor
clusters.neutral_headline: Politician Brothers Convicted Of Ordering Murder

items.title: Politician brothers convicted in Brazil for ordering murder of prominent councillor
items.standfirst: Marielle Franco's murder at the age of 38 in Rio de Janeiro sparked protests across Brazil.
items.content: Marielle Franco's murder at the age of 38 in Rio de Janeiro sparked protests across Brazil.

items.title: Brazil politicians convicted for ordering murder of black activist councilor
items.standfirst: Brazil's Supreme Court on Wednesday convicted two former lawmakers of ordering the 2018 assassination of Rio de Janeiro councilwoman Marielle Franco, a popular black activist whose murder exposed deep ties between politics and organized crime. Franco, an LGBTQ activist who grew up in a favela and became an outspoken critic of Rio's powerful militia groups, was 38 when she was gunned down in the city center alongside her driver, Anderson Gomes.
items.content: Brazil's Supreme Court on Wednesday convicted two former lawmakers of ordering the 2018 assassination of Rio de Janeiro councilwoman Marielle Franco, a popular black activist whose murder exposed deep ties between politics and organized crime. Franco, an LGBTQ activist who grew up in a favela and became an outspoken critic of Rio's powerful militia groups, was 38 when she was gunned down in the city center alongside her driver, Anderson Gomes.

items.title: Former Brazil lawmakers convicted of ordering murder of Rio councilwoman Marielle Franco
items.standfirst: Two former politicians were convicted by Brazil’s Supreme Court on Wednesday of ordering the 2018 assassination of Rio de Janeiro councilwoman and activist Marielle Franco, whose murder exposed a web of corruption linking political figures to organised crime.
items.content: Two former politicians were convicted by Brazil’s Supreme Court on Wednesday of ordering the 2018 assassination of Rio de Janeiro councilwoman and activist Marielle Franco, whose murder exposed a web of corruption linking political figures to organised crime.

items.title: Brazilian politician brothers convicted of ordering murder of Rio city councillor
items.standfirst: João Francisco Inácio Brazão and Domingos Inácio Brazão sentenced for murder of Marielle Franco, a gay Black woman and rising political star Two influential Brazilian politician brothers have been convicted by Brazil’s supreme court of ordering the murder of Marielle Franco, the Rio de Janeiro city councillor, nearly eight years ago.João Francisco Inácio Brazão, the former congressman known as Chiquinho, and the former adviser to Rio’s court of auditors Domingos Inácio Brazão were sentenced to 76 years and three months in prison for the murders of Franco, 38, and her driver, Anderson Gomes, 39. Continue reading...
items.content: João Francisco Inácio Brazão and Domingos Inácio Brazão sentenced for murder of Marielle Franco, a gay Black woman and rising political star Two influential Brazilian politician brothers have been convicted by Brazil’s supreme court of ordering the murder of Marielle Franco, the Rio de Janeiro city councillor, nearly eight years ago.João Francisco Inácio Brazão, the former congressman known as Chiquinho, and the former adviser to Rio’s court of auditors Domingos Inácio Brazão were sentenced to 76 years and three months in prison for the murders of Franco, 38, and her driver, Anderson Gomes, 39. Continue reading...

items.title: Franco murder exposed 'deep fissures in Brazilian society'
items.standfirst: A five-judge panel of Brazil’s Supreme Court will rule Wednesday on the future of the suspects accused of plotting the 2018 killing of Rio de Janeiro councilwoman Marielle Franco and her driver Anderson Gomes, a case that continues to stir emotions in the politically divided nation. France 24 correspondent Tim Vickery has the latest.
items.content: A five-judge panel of Brazil’s Supreme Court will rule Wednesday on the future of the suspects accused of plotting the 2018 killing of Rio de Janeiro councilwoman Marielle Franco and her driver Anderson Gomes, a case that continues to stir emotions in the politically divided nation. France 24 correspondent Tim Vickery has the latest.

items.title: Brazilian politicians accused of ordering murder of Rio councillor go on trial
items.standfirst: Chiquinho and Domingos Brazão accused of ordering shooting of Marielle Franco and her driver in 2018Brazil’s supreme court has opened the trial of politicians accused of ordering the 2018 murder of Rio de Janeiro councillor Marielle Franco, a case that exposed deep ties between politics and organised crime in the city.Franco, an activist who grew up in a favela and became an outspoken critic of Rio’s powerful militia groups, was 38 when she was shot dead in the city centre alongside her driver, Anderson Gomes. Continue reading...
items.content: Chiquinho and Domingos Brazão accused of ordering shooting of Marielle Franco and her driver in 2018Brazil’s supreme court has opened the trial of politicians accused of ordering the 2018 murder of Rio de Janeiro councillor Marielle Franco, a case that exposed deep ties between politics and organised crime in the city.Franco, an activist who grew up in a favela and became an outspoken critic of Rio’s powerful militia groups, was 38 when she was shot dead in the city centre alongside her driver, Anderson Gomes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Brothers convicted of ordering councilor's murder
Murder exposed deep ties between politics and crime
Convicted brothers sentenced to prison
Victim was a prominent black activist councilor
Case sparked protests across Brazil

clusters.title: Israel responsible for two-thirds of record 129 press killings in 2025, says CPJ
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Responsible For Most Journalist Killings

items.title: Israel responsible for two-thirds of record 129 press killings in 2025, says CPJ
items.standfirst: Committee to Protect Journalists report says Israel also to blame for 81% of ‘intentionally targeted’ journalist killings The deadly toll on journalists in the Gaza warA record 129 journalists and media workers were killed in the course of their work in 2025, two-thirds of them by Israeli forces, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ).It was the second consecutive year in which killings of members of the press reached unprecedented levels, and the second year running in which Israel was responsible for roughly two-thirds of the total, the New York-based independent organisation, which documents attacks on journalists worldwide, said in its annual report published on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Committee to Protect Journalists report says Israel also to blame for 81% of ‘intentionally targeted’ journalist killings The deadly toll on journalists in the Gaza warA record 129 journalists and media workers were killed in the course of their work in 2025, two-thirds of them by Israeli forces, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ).It was the second consecutive year in which killings of members of the press reached unprecedented levels, and the second year running in which Israel was responsible for roughly two-thirds of the total, the New York-based independent organisation, which documents attacks on journalists worldwide, said in its annual report published on Wednesday. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel kills more journalists than any nation on record: Media watchdog
items.standfirst: Israel responsible for 84 of 129 journalist killings in 2025 tracked by the Committee to Protect Journalists.
items.content: Israel responsible for 84 of 129 journalist killings in 2025 tracked by the Committee to Protect Journalists.

ai_summary: Israel responsible for two thirds of journalist killings

clusters.title: US consular services in illegal Israeli settlement in West Bank condemned

items.title: US consular services in illegal Israeli settlement in West Bank condemned
items.standfirst: US move to provide consular services in Efrat settlement slammed as breach of international law.
items.content: US move to provide consular services in Efrat settlement slammed as breach of international law.

items.title: US to offer passport services to citizens in illegal West Bank settlements
items.standfirst: Israel welcomes move described by Palestinian Authority as undermining possibility of an independent stateThe US will provide on-site consular services in two Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank for the first time, breaking with previous policy, in a move that has been criticised by Palestinian officials as “a clear violation of international law”.In a post on X, the US embassy in Jerusalem said that as part of an initiative to mark the 250th anniversary of US independence, it would provide Americans with routine passport services in the West Bank settlement of Efrat on Friday “for one day only”. Continue reading...
items.content: Israel welcomes move described by Palestinian Authority as undermining possibility of an independent stateThe US will provide on-site consular services in two Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank for the first time, breaking with previous policy, in a move that has been criticised by Palestinian officials as “a clear violation of international law”.In a post on X, the US embassy in Jerusalem said that as part of an initiative to mark the 250th anniversary of US independence, it would provide Americans with routine passport services in the West Bank settlement of Efrat on Friday “for one day only”. Continue reading...

items.content: The remote Yonaguni island lies on the frontlines of self-governing Taiwan's growing tensions with China.

items.title: Japan to deploy missiles to island near Taiwan by 2031, says defence minister
items.standfirst: Surface-to-air missiles, which are capable of shooting down aircraft and ballistic missiles, will be located on Yonaguni, Japan’s westernmost islandJapan will deploy missiles to a tiny island near Taiwan within five years, its defence minister has said, in a move that is likely to inflame tensions with China.The surface-to-air missiles, which are capable of shooting down aircraft and ballistic missiles, will be located on Yonaguni – Japan’s westernmost island – by March 2031, Shinjiro Koizumi said. Continue reading...
items.content: Surface-to-air missiles, which are capable of shooting down aircraft and ballistic missiles, will be located on Yonaguni, Japan’s westernmost islandJapan will deploy missiles to a tiny island near Taiwan within five years, its defence minister has said, in a move that is likely to inflame tensions with China.The surface-to-air missiles, which are capable of shooting down aircraft and ballistic missiles, will be located on Yonaguni – Japan’s westernmost island – by March 2031, Shinjiro Koizumi said. Continue reading...
